body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. LOUIS ARENA Scent of a Firefighter Louis Arena loved being a firefighter, and one of the ways he showed it was this: He would return to his Staten Island home from Ladder Company 5 and tell his wife, Wanda, ''Smell my head.'' Mrs. Arena, 31, was crazy about
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; A Man Who Smelled of Smoke, an Avid Golfer, a Planter of Love Notes

body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. LOUIS F. AVERSANO JR. A Morning Chat With Fish Louis F. Aversano Jr. liked to take care of everybody and everything. Especially his fish. At his home in Manalapan, N.J., Mr. Aversano, 58, kept a suburban-sized aquarium with five fish that he doted on. ''Those
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; A Recipe-Following Fireman, a Wiseacre Dad and a First-Time Visitor

body: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 393 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 335. In all, 4,979 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives. NURAL and SHAKILA MIAH The Voice of a Deer Long ago in Bangladesh, Nural Miah's grand father hunted birds in the jungle.
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; A Hunting Tradition Is Upheld, Along With a Bond Between Cousins

body: Marjorie Severence, from Queens, voted in a primary election yesterday for the first time in her life. She is 67, and said it just felt urgent and relevant to vote now. But Monica Watson, 29, from Brooklyn, did not go to the polls, because to spend time electing a leader no longer seemed important to her. David Stypmann, at 63, a lifelong Democrat
title: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: VOICES; A Shift in the Ritual, and Meaning, of Voting

body: The primary election scheduled for Sept. 11 but postponed because of the terrorist attack will be held today. Absentee ballots submitted before Sept. 11 count, but votes cast at polling places that day do not. This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County. All are Democratic
title: Voting Today in New York

body: At the Studio Museum in Harlem, people watched slides of work by an artist no longer with them. Under the ornately carved ceiling of the Harmonie Club, a friend was remembered as fondly for his love of Prada suits as for his anchor-like presence. In St. Patrick's Church in Huntington, N.Y., hundreds wore buttons bearing a photograph of a swanlike
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MEMORIALS; Across Region, a Daily Wave of Remembrance

body: This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County today. All are Democratic primary choices except for the borough presidency in Staten Island, where there is only a Republican primary. Poll hours are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Mayor Mark Green Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum Comptroller William
title: Primary Choices

body: Among the myriad open City Council seats this year, few have attracted as many candidates with the political credentials and connections as those in the six-way race in the Democratic primary in the 39th Council District. The candidates' résumés cover the spectrum of local politics in what is commonly known as brownstone Brooklyn, but their names
title: Boasts in 6-Way Race: Experience and Endorsements

body: Brooklyn voters have a chance this year to enliven New York's City Council with the kind of energy, intelligence and independence unrivaled in city politics in many years. Here are our recommendations in seven important Democratic races in the Sept. 11 primary. 33rd District (Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Williamsburg, Greenpoint): David
title: Council Endorsements: Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: Thanks for your article on the Kensington section of Brooklyn [Aug. 5]. We bought one of those huge co-ops on Ocean Parkway just about six months ago. Before this we rented for about a decade, first in Park Slope, then Clinton Hill, then Fort Greene. Not only was the purchase of our current two-bedroom apartment the best investment
title: The Happy Life In Kensington

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

body: A six-day August heat wave came to a soggy end yesterday afternoon when thunderstorms descended on most of the region. But there was no letup for utilities, as the storm knocked down power lines and electricity was cut off at tens of thousands of households in the Northeast. Lightning and winds gusting at nearly 40 miles per hour in some places
title: Storms End Hot Spell, but Conjure Their Own Problems

body: UNTIL they drove by the house they ended up buying -- it had a wraparound porch and five stained-glass windows -- Christopher James Quinn and his wife, Nanette Fuentes, were only dimly aware of Kensington's existence. They visited the house many times, bought it in March 2000, renovated it top to bottom and grew fond of their little-known
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Kensington; An Old Neighborhood Is Rediscovered
If You're Thinking of Living In; Kensington, Brooklyn

body: A 19-year-man died and the friend he was apparently teaching how to drive was in very critical condition yesterday after their van raced off the edge of a Brooklyn pier and plunged into Gowanus Bay, the police said. The cause was unclear, but witnesses saw a burgundy Chevrolet Astro van smash through two metal rail barriers at the edge of Pier 4,
title: 1 Killed and 1 Severely Hurt When Van Runs Off Pier

body: When the long-troubled John Jay High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, closed its doors for good a week ago today, the goodbyes were tinged with a mix of emotions. Some students and teachers at the academically struggling school said they believed that they were being forced out by middle-class neighborhood parents looking for a new school for their
title: Reinventing John Jay High Amid Charges of Exclusion

body: A 64-year-old military buff who the police said took a pipe bomb to a friend's party in Brooklyn Heights Tuesday night was charged with arson and reckless endangerment yesterday as he lay in a hospital burn ward recovering from the injuries he suffered when the bomb went off. title: Police Charge Brooklyn Man In Explosion at Friend's Party

body: Twenty years ago, an empty house in Queens first told Anthony Russini that his 15-month-old son was gone. No one answered the door. The grass was thigh high. Barry and Judith Smiley had disappeared with the boy. ''And then it's just a void,'' Mr. Russini said today. ''You're lost.'' He stood with his brother, Richie, and his father, Dick, in his
title: Family Rejoices for a Found Son, but Still Grieves for a Lost Childhood
